comments.commentBody:
Vote for Sanders!

Better ideas without the cray cray.

I agree with Trump on his tax policies. But I still don't trust him. He's angry, impulsive & entitled. The very definition of a loose canon.

He's absolutely the last person who should have the keys to the nuclear suitcase....
I'm actually kinda interested to hear from the clown bus on this one.

Supply side economist Arthur Laffer suggested that when the marginal tax is reduced the tax receipts would increase because the rich can spent extra money to create jobs for the rest of us. The whole scheme is a sinister hoax as pointed out by David Stockman (Reagan’s budgetary director). The actual results from the Reagan tax cut were that the rich become richer, the government budgetary gap increased and there was nothing that trickled down for people on the street. The marginal tax rate needs to be increased to lessen the wealth gap between the 99 percent and the rich. The loopholes need to be closed so people like Romney will pay more than 14% of his income as tax.  The rich need to pay more tax in exchange for long term social stability and sustainable democracy because they have the most to loss when society collapses

You sound like a Democrat.

Welcome.
Trump may not be the man for the job, but he sure has the message

If Trump taxes carried interest as ordinary income in hedge funds and taxes Wall Street traders short term trading and MEANS it, he may get my vote and I am a Bernie Sanders Democrat, whom I would vote for in a New York trumpet second, if HE gets the Dem nomination. For 35 years I worked on Wall Street and today I wouldn't touch those bandits with a ten-foot pole. Warren Buffett knows more than every slovenly banker in NYC put together. Michael Lewis is right. The system is rigged ! So much for that " free market capitalism" from pseudo intellectuals like Grover Norquist and his phony Club for Billionaires Growth gorging their wallets. Trump may sound crazy to many. Crazy like a fox.

Trump and Sanders recognize the same problems.
The difference is that Sanders will invariably solve everything with more government, which is categorically unsustainable.
Trump, if he gets his way, will work towards a leaner government.
Unless you don't count voter suppression and the finger on the scales by SCOTUS in 2000.....
Everyone gets the Government they deserve. GOP'rs did it to themselves...AGAIN!!

It's already near 40%.
Flat or fair tax with elimination of loopholes is better, with an increased state/local income or capital gains tax offset by reduced property tax.
How about tax 99%. HA! I mean I mean might as well tax everyone 100% that would be easier and would mean more tax revenue.
Good for you.  If you separate the personality from the message, it's really a lot of common sense.

When the economy crashed so horribly under George W. Bush because of mistakes they made having to do with banking and lots of other things, I don't think the Democrats would have done that,"...................... Donald Trump

It is State legislatures that have made war against Unions, on behalf of the !% donor base.

It was federal laws which enabled pension funds to be gambled in the Casino of Wall Street that led to the insolvency of these once well-funded retirement savings of members who EARNED those pensions.

It was lobbyists writing the tax codes that allow companies to hide their income with paper-work filings that did nothing but meet the satisfy the laws they themselves wrote; moving assets offshore, calling a 2-person European office a "headquarters" etc.

I think it's time to end all of this when even an orange-haired billionaire with a room-temperature IQ can see how wrong it is.

Trump will likely see the folly of raising taxes on anybody and that taxes and union pressures have driven U.S. industry overseas. He will see the evil of "graduated taxation" as Marxist and destructive to capitalism as he looks at the entire economic picture. Otherwise, he will lose most of his support base. The last thing they desire is more of the same "tax and spend" matra of the Donkey Party.
Those who support Sanders are like snakes eating their own tails.  His Marxist ideas would destroy the Country's ability to be a 'mama' to his komrades.

I worked in research for a major pharmaceutical company for 30 years. What would be insane is if the studies were conducted (and paid for) by some independent agency that did not have the commitment to or the understanding of the nuances of the drug being tested in a clinical trial. The clinicians who run the studies are paid by the drug companies, but in the same manor you would pay for a plumber or an electrician. They have lots of work and a reputation to maintain, and they can walk away from your study any time they choose. Further the studies are run in compliance with and under the strict scrutiny of hospital medical boards and the FDA. In 30 years I never saw or even heard of anyone trying to fudge or misrepresent efficacy or safety data. The fact is that clinical trials are often complex and difficult, but deliberate misrepresentation is a figment of your imagination.
Wow; there's no end to the anti-Trump slander.  It satisfies me greatly to see that the more you do it, the more his polls go up!

It is difficult for me to support a candidate who openly mocks minorities (Hispanic, Asian, etc), channels xenophobia, and whose grand designs for the Presidency is to build a wall.

Color me underwhelmed.
...actually, every parasitic deadbeat's "nightmare."
Trump has said he is for a Canadian style single payer health care system.

Can you provide us with the sources for your "evidence"  about the thousands coming from places not ravaged by war?  What is the proportion of economic refugees to war refugees? Are all the refugees Muslim?  55% of how many applicants were  denied?  Cite some statistics from reliable sources.

Affirmative action or other quota/pdeudo-quota systems have been used in many countries including India long before they gained popularity in the US. The result of such policies is out there. Instead of declaring judgement I urge readers to do a little bit of research. You can start by reading Thomas Sowell's book:
http://www.tsowell.com/affirmact.htm

It's a fight for limited resources in a country with unlimited population: 4 times the US population on a third of the land area, 12 times the population density.  Essentially, the country can provide a decent-ish living to 10-20% of the population, and there is a war to the death to get into that group.  This is just one battle in that war.
Almost inedible, my kids wouldn't eat it! My husband and I only ate it after I added soy sauce, hoisin, ginger and green onions to the mix. I would definitely not make this again.
By your logic, Texas should be part of Mexico.

I don't see any logic in your statement. U.S. has been a federated union throughout its history and Texas has been part of the federation since 1845.  Decentralization proposed by Poroshenko is not even about federalism or autonomy to the break-away regions.. According to the Constitutional law voted yesterday in Rada, no special status will be given to "the certain territories in Luhansk and Donetsk regions.

Texas was in fact a break away province of Mexico and an independent territory before annexation to the US. The "nationalists" in Texas rebelled against the Mexican government in part because of Mexico's abolition of slavery in 1835, a fact never mentioned in Alamo folklore. Texas planters were bringing slaves in from Mississippi and Louisiana by the thousands, joining the cotton boom of the 1830's. They decided to revolt rather than cede their property to the new Mexican law. By 1860 they decided to revolt against the US government for the same reasons.

As far as Eastern Ukraine is concerned the NYT also neglects to mention the outright fascists who are part of this nationalist movement and who openly display the swastika. Autonomy in the east will at least pave the way for a cessation of hostilities while at least nominally keeping the country in tact.

21 year old Mr. Igor Gumenyuk who allegedly threw the grenade is an active duty servicemen in the battalion "Sich" funded by the radical nationalist party led by Tyagnibok, an active member of the Maidan troika. Senator McCain honored him with a handshake on one of his visits to Kiev. What NYT, unfortunately, failed to mention is that this national guard battalion is subordinated to the Ministry of Interior that is to Minister Avakov himself.

The issue of decentralization is obfuscated as a demand of Putin and a concession to Russia. In fact, the Minsk 2 agreement was mediated by Hollande and Merkel and in their recent meeting with Poroshenko in Berlin (August 24) they insisted that decentralization be implemented. Moreover, in his speech at Rada the head of the ruling party, Mr. Lutsenko, stated today that decentralization was one of the demands of the Maidan. Mr. Saakashvili, governor of the Odessa oblast, too, supported the decentralization and even revoked the free cities under the Magdeburg law in the Middle Ages. By insisting that this was a concession to the Kremlin with a gun to his head in Debaltsevo, NYT further confuses its readership. If this was a concession to Putin, then NYT is giving a credit to the radical nationalists of Tyagnibok, listed as number 5 anti-Semite by the Wiesenthal Center.

Yes, but I'm sure that we can all agree that these reactionary bigots would not have actually fired on the police during the Maidan protests in 2014, as some are claiming, even if their Nuland directed neocon handlers (CIA) had directed them to, and even if it would have gained their cause some heavy propaganda advantage in the flaccidly complicit western media.
Actually, that is the way much of the world is.....and frankly, especially if they  are from highly conservative religions such as Islam.
Some things in history are inevitable, Ray. The "Arab Spring" was at least a century in the making, if not much longer.
